720603f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720603f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The area given by the photographer as the "Indian Planting Ground" of Isham Meadows. The writer believes same to be that marginal strip on the easterly side of Inwood Hill at the Harlem River as viewed north westward
and showing the Bronx Shore at the right.
1904.
Brown Bros.

720613f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720613f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The area given by the photographer as "The Knoll" of Dyckman Meadows. The writer believes same to be the locality divided by Dyckman Street near the north (Hudson) River and where today (1939) a bridge carrying the Henry Hudson Parkway spans the gap. He also infers that it is Dyckman Street seen in the midground and that the present park is the hill on the far side of same as observed in a northwestward direction. For additional photos of this area at this date - See files under Broadway.
1904
Brown Bros.

720610f.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720610f.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The Museum of Indian Art and Library of the
Dyckman Institute.
January 14, 1932.
S.N. Fishblatt.
International News Photos.

720611f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720611f-a.text:
INwood Hill Park: The Museum of Indian Art and Library of the Dyckman Institute and the big Tulip tree in that portion of the park on the bend in the Harlem River. The photographer is viewing towards the latter, showing the Iron Works Peninsula that causes the afore-mentioned loop and which in the near future will be eliminated; the U.S. Government cutting a canal through in 1937.

January 14, 1932
B.N. Fishblatt
International News Photos.

720612f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720612f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The Tulip tree and the Dyckman Institute, viewing towards the Iron Works Peninsula on the Bronx shore of the Harlem River.
January 14, 1932.
S. N. Fishblatt.
International News Photos.

720602f-b.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720602f-b.text:
Inwood Hill Park1 A set of three views of the Episcopal House of Mercy, viewed in a northward and northeastward (2 and 3) direction from a point above the Jewish Hospital on
Dyckman Street and Bolton Road.
Sanuary 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720602f-c.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720602f-c.text:
Inwood Hill Park1 A set of three views of the Episcopal House of Mercy, viewed in a northward and northeastward (2 and 3) direction from a point above the Jewish Hospital on
Dyckman Street and Bolton Road.
Sanuary 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720601f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720601f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The Episcopal House of Mercy that is also known
as the Home for Wayward Girls.
January 14, 1932.
S. N. Fishblatt
International News Photos.
1NA A  A27)D cy  NE. 2A E627

720599f-c.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720599f-c.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of three views photographed the same day and showing different aspects of this wooded area. No. 1 is in a westward direction towards the Jersey highlands and shows the old foundations and the roof of the Jewish Memorial Hospital. Today (1938) these have disappeared, the Henry Hudson Parkway having incorporated same. To the left is Dyckman Street.
No. 2 is northward along the Hudson River and across the Harlem River gap showing the New York Central Railroad bridge across the latter. On the Bronx shore appears the Casa Victoria, a modern apartment house. No. 3 shows a tulip tree below the House of Mercy. This is not to be confused with the big tulip tree near the Indian
Museum.
January 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720599f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720599f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of three views photographed the same day and showing different aspects of this wooded area. No. 1 is in a westward direction towards the Jersey highlands and shows the old foundations and the roof of the Jewish Memorial Hospital. Today (1938) these have disappeared, the Henry Hudson Parkway having incorporated same. To the left is Dyckman Street.
No. 2 is northward along the Hudson River and across the Harlem River gap showing the New York Central Railroad bridge across the latter. On the Bronx shore appears the Casa Victoria, a modern apartment house. No. 3 shows a tulip tree below the House of Mercy. This is not to be confused with the big tulip tree near the Indian
Museum.
January 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720599f-b.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of three views photographed the same day and showing different aspects of this wooded area. No. 1 is in a westward direction towards the Jersey highlands and shows the old foundations and the roof of the Jewish Memorial Hospital. Today (1938) these have disappeared, the Henry Hudson Parkway having incorporated same. To the left is Dyckman Street.
No. 2 is northward along the Hudson River and across the Harlem River gap showing the New York Central Railroad bridge across the latter. On the Bronx shore appears the Casa Victoria, a modern apartment house. No. 3 shows a tulip tree below the House of Mercy. This is not to be confused with the big tulip tree near the Indian

January 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720608f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720608f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of two views showing an individual, one Mike Fesslian, his shack and bee hives in a location slightly north of
the House of Mercy.
January 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720608f-b.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720608f-b.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of two views showing an individual, one Mike Fesslian, his shack and bee hives in a location slightly north of
the House of Mercy.
January 14, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

720606f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park - [Jewish Memorial Hospital.]
720606f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A southward view along the marginal lands from a point slightly above Dyckman Street, showing a new bulkhead line under construction. The photographer is viewing towards Fort Tryon Park which appears in the right background. On the left is the Jewish Memorial Hospital which in the near future will be demolished; the
Henry Hudson Parkway running through its site.
June 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.
720606f-a.folder: Inwood Hill Park & [Jewish Memorial Hospital.], Manhattan, NY

720604f-b.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720604f-b.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of three views northward along the marginal lands between the New York Central Railroad tracks (right) and the North (Hudson) River, showing same being filled in under the direction of the West Side Improvement Project. Nos. 2 and 3 are successively northward and the latter shows the Railroad Bridge crossing the Harlem River to the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx from this most northerly tip of Manhattan. The photographer's original vantage point is slightly above Dyckman Street.
April 3, 1934.
P. L. Sperr.

720604f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720604f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of three views northward along the marginal lands between the New York Central Railroad tracks (right) and the North (Hudson) River, showing same being filled in under the direction of the West Side Improvement Project. Nos. 2 and 3 are successively northward and the latter shows the Railroad Bridge crossing the Harlem River to the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx from this most northerly tip of Manhattan. 720600f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720600f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: Different aspects of the northeasterly side of this wooded area located in the northern terminus of Manhattan. This set of three views is photographed in the vicinity of the Indian Museum, same appearing in Nos. 1 and 2. The bathers in the foreground of the latter are about to bathe in the Harlem River which flows past this side.
June 22, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

720600f-c.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720600f-c.text:
Inwood Hill Park: Different aspects of the northeasterly side of this wooded area located in the northern terminus of Manhattan. This set of three views is photographed in the vicinity of the Indian Museum, same appearing in Nos. 1 and 2. The bathers in the foreground of the latter are about to bathe in the Harlem River which flows past this side.

P. L. Sperr.

720607f-a.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720607f-a.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of two views of the Museum of Indian Art and Library of the Dyckman Institute which overlooks the Harlem River towards the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx.
June 26, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

720607f-b.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720607f-b.text:
Inwood Hill Park: A set of two views of the Museum of Indian Art and Library of the Dyckman Institute which overlooks the Harlem River towards the Spuyten Duyvil section of the Bronx.
June 26, 1935.

720605f-c.title: Manhattan: Inwood Hill Park.
720605f-c.text:
Inwood Hill Park: The marginal strip between same and the Hudson River and thru which runs the New York Central Railroad tracks and Bolton Road (right, atop embankment. To the left appears the Palisades on the
Jersey shore.
View 2 is the same area and is identified by the photographer, as the boat-house, north of Dyckman Street and observed from the Ferry dock.
View 1: October 26, 1927
View 2: April 14, 1936
P. L. Sperr
S) The same area, a few years later.
P.L Sperr  August 2, 1939
